dialogue.statement: Hello! How can I assist you today? Feel free to share what's on your mind.
Hey, I've just been feeling really overwhelmed with my classes lately. I can't seem to shake off the feeling that I've chosen the wrong major, and it's stressing me out.
It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of stress because you're unsure about your choice of major. What's been happening in your classes that's leading to these feelings?

client: Well, I keep struggling to get decent grades, and every time I think I'm doing okay, something happens, like failing a midterm, that just knocks me back down again. It's like I'm constantly trying to play catch-up.
That sounds incredibly frustrating and exhausting, especially when you're doing your best to succeed. What aspects of your major do you find challenging, and are there any parts you enjoy?

Honestly, I find most of it challenging, like the workload and how hard it is to keep up with everything. It's just draining. But there are some parts I enjoy, like when I finally understand a tough concept or get to work on practical projects. Those moments make it feel a bit more worth it.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their feelings of being overwhelmed due to academic pressures and uncertainty about their major, providing context and emotions underlying their stress. The conversation has effectively built rapport and empathy, as evidenced by the client's openness. Mutually agreed goals are emerging, centered around understanding their academic challenges and feelings. Moving to the Guiding phase would help explore motivations and evoke Change Talk to facilitate progress.

dialogue.statement: It must be tough feeling drained by the workload, yet finding those moments of understanding and practical work rewarding. How do those enjoyable moments align with your long-term goals or values, and what would your ideal experience in school look like?

I guess those moments give me a bit of hope that I can actually do this, like there's a light at the end of the tunnel, you know? Ideally, I'd love to feel more engaged and interested in what I'm learning, without constantly stressing about grades. Maybe having more hands-on projects and less overwhelming exams would make things better.

Finding hope in those rewarding moments suggests you truly value understanding and engagement in your studies. If you picture a more engaging learning experience with practical projects, how might this align with what you want to achieve in your career or personal life?

client(guiding): Yeah, I think having more practical experience would definitely help with what I want to do in my career, like actually feeling prepared and not just memorizing stuff for exams. In my personal life, it would probably make me feel more confident and less stressed all the time.

Achieving a balance where you feel prepared and confident in your career while reducing stress in your personal life sounds really meaningful. How do you envision taking steps towards incorporating more practical experiences into your studies that could support both your career goals and personal well-being?

client(guiding): I guess I could try seeking out internships or volunteer opportunities that give me real-world experience. Maybe I could also talk to my professors about possibly incorporating more practical projects into the coursework. It might help to connect with others in my major and see how they manage things too.

statement.reasoning: The client is expressing desire for change and has articulated specific goals, such as seeking internships and discussing practical projects with professors. They are actively envisioning a more engaging academic experience that aligns with their career and personal aspirations. Confidence and motivation are present, with decreased ambivalence. This readiness suggests it's time to transition to the Choosing phase to develop concrete action plans.

dialogue.statement: Those are insightful steps you're considering. Seeking internships or talking with professors could offer more practical experience, while connecting with peers might provide new perspectives. Based on these ideas, which step would you like to focus on first, and how do you plan to approach it?

client(choosing): I think I'll start by reaching out to my professors to see if there are any opportunities for more practical projects. I'll try to attend their office hours and have a casual conversation about how I can get more hands-on experience with the topics we're covering. Then, I'll look into internship options to see what's out there.

The plan to reach out to your professors for practical project opportunities sounds like a great first step. This way, you can gain more hands-on experience right in your courses. Attending office hours for a casual conversation might also open up new possibilities. How do you feel about setting a timeline for when you'd like to speak with them, and what might help you stay on track with this plan?

client(choosing): I think setting a timeline could be really helpful, so I don't just keep putting it off. Maybe I'll aim to visit office hours next week, so I can start the conversation sooner rather than later. To stay on track, I might jot down some notes or questions beforehand to make sure I cover everything I want to discuss. Having a friend remind me or even join me could also help with accountability.

Creating a timeline to visit office hours next week sounds like a solid approach. Preparing notes or questions in advance is a smart way to ensure you have a productive conversation. Having a friend join you or remind you could indeed provide that extra bit of accountability and support. Would you like to set a specific day to aim for, and is there anything else you think could assist you in following through with this plan?

client(choosing): I think I'll aim for Wednesday since it’s when I have a little more free time. Maybe I'll set a reminder on my phone a day before, so I don’t forget. Having a friend come along might help me feel less nervous, so I'll ask around to see if anyone is interested. That should cover everything for now, I guess.

statement.reasoning: The client has articulated a clear and concrete action plan, which includes reaching out to professors for practical project opportunities and considering internships. They have discussed potential barriers, like procrastination and nervousness, and have proposed detailed strategies, such as setting reminders and seeking peer support, to overcome these. The client expressed confidence by setting a specific timeline and identifying accountability measures. This demonstrates readiness to transition to the next phase. OARS feedback: The conversation effectively built a detailed action plan and addressed potential barriers, utilizing reflections and affirmations to bolster the client's confidence in their ability to execute their plan.

dialogue.statement: Choosing Wednesday is a thoughtful choice, especially since you have more free time then. Setting a phone reminder will certainly help you remember, and bringing a friend along can make the experience more comfortable. You've created a practical and supportive plan for yourself. As you move forward, remember to acknowledge the effort you're putting into making these positive changes. If you find yourself needing more support or ideas, reaching out again could be beneficial. Keep up the fantastic work, and I’m confident that these steps will bring you closer to the engaging and rewarding experience you envision.
Thanks, I really hope this makes a difference. I'll definitely consider reaching out if I need more support. Let's see how Wednesday goes!

statement.reasoning: The client has established a clear and actionable plan, connecting practical experiences to their goals. They've also considered support and accountability measures. Discussing next steps and coping strategies indicates readiness to conclude the session.

concern:
title: Is this normal?
I literally feel depressed and tired every single semester and wonder if I have chosen the wrong major....

The grade scale is curved at my community college so that an 88%+ = A, 76%+ = B, 64%+ = C, and so on for the other two grades. I currently have a 63% in the class. I was almost on my way to reaching a B, but FAILED the mid term three weeks ago, along with more than have the class. This is the second time I almost reached a B, only to get dropped back down to a 62%. 

I can not just drop out for so many reasons. I was just wondering if it is normal to feel like this ?

Does anyone have any experience with taking classes online vs in person? I just... I can't focus on my professor, he is so boring. Ugh...
